But how wonderful are 'che vicissitudes of fortune and of human affairs! The fiood burst in wild rage upon him, who rashly thought to brave the unruly inundation that menaced the quiet of a neighboring nation. Four regiments of the Strelitz, which lay upon the frontier of Lithuania had nefariously plotted to change the sovereignty. The regiment of Theodosia abandoned Viasma, the Athanasian regi- ment quitted Piala, the Isano-Tzernovio-VVlodomir- ian left Ostheba‚ and the Ticchonian quitted Dorogo- busa, in which places they were in garrison. They drove away the loyal officers that happened to be among them, distributed military rank among them- selves,— the readiest for crime being held the fittest for command. At once they menaced death to all in their next neighborhood if they would not freely join their party, or should resist their design.

Many reports spread through Moscow about the danger that was so near at hand, but what real truth was in them nobody knew: until at length the meeting of the BoyarS, their consultations repeated day after day, their assembling by night, and their assiduous conferenees might have proved to anybody how grave a business it was, and what imminent need there was to press on their conclusions to maturity.
